label.string: The word ‘career’ for many people implies upward progression and promotion. In reality, a career is about acquiring work experience and includes professional studies, skills training, work experience and vocational work. The key to career management is about you being influential in the type of work you do and the awareness of opportunities for progression or development.

textView.string: Career Management Life Cycle This App is designed for you to take charge of your career, following the App around the four quadrants of Aspire’s career life cycle which are The career life cycle theme will continue throughout the App.

label.text: Aspire Development UK Limited 2014 Copyright © All Rights Reserved.
Suite 2.15 Holmfield Mills, Holdsworth Road, Halifax, HX3 6SN

label.string: Knowing and articulating what you are good at is a critical step toward being able to sell yourself in your CV and at a job interview. Your skills make a statement about what you offer a potential employer, how you’re different from others, and what you’ll bring to a job.

label.text: In this section of the app you will find information around three stages of a career:

label.string: Knowing and articulating what you are good at is a critical step toward being able to sell yourself in your CV and at a job interview. Your skills make a statement about what you offer a potential employer, how you’re different from others, and what you’ll bring to a job.

label.text: In this section of the app you will find information around three stages of a career:

navigationItem.title: Section 4 STRATEGIES to getting a healthy career.

label.string: The Career Management App is designed to be a practical aid to managing your career. It’s a self-help study of Career Management, you can either go through each of the four quadrant topics, completing the tasks and tools in them, or dip in and out of different sections depending upon your situation or where you are in your career.

navigationItem.title: Section 1 What you WANT from your career?
What you WANT from your career?

label.string: Our values and motives have a strong influence over our behaviours, and the kind of job or career that we want. Knowing what our values and motives are is important because they shape what we do.

label.text: Use Tool 2 - Values and Motives to help you start to review and prioritise what’s important to you in your career.

label.string: What’s important to me about a job or career?

Task; List all the areas that are ‘important to you’, and place them in priority order of importance, so that you end up with your top five values and motives. Then consider how these values and motives are met in your current role, or could be met in a future role.

It is worth thinking about the type of work you enjoy and are interested in. Have you noticed that when people are following a career or doing a job that they’re really interested in, they tend to be happy and content in what they do? If you’re interested in what you do, then it’s likely that you’ll want to develop the skills and ability to do the job really well. So finding a job or career that really interests is important.

Tool 3 – Career Choices explores career preferences, ranging from a preference to mainly work with people or data or things or ideas, or a combination. This will be important, because if your main preference in a job is to work a lot with people, and yet you find yourself in a job that requires you to sit in an office, on your own and deal with data, it is likely that you’ll soon get frustrated and not perform at your best.
Consider the following ‘values and motives’ statements below and indicate by pressing the yes(Green) or no(white) button to indicate which ones are so important to you that you.
‘Must have’ Very Important to me
• Managing, controlling or influencing events and processes.
• Managing and leading other people in a team.
2. Achievement:
• Achievements which are satisfying for their own sake (e.g. doing a good job).
• Achievements which have exceeded existing standards of excellence.
• Achievements which are satisfying because of the extrinsic rewards they bring (e.g. recognition, promotion, money).
• Gaining recognition and higher status for the things I’ve done or achieved.
• Acquiring and using technical skills (e.g. electrical, computer, accounting).
• Personal development and skills training.
• Developing leadership skills and behaviours.
• Mastering knowledge and ideas in the sciences, social sciences, or technology.
• Earning money for its own sake (e.g. a symbol of success).
• Earning money to help me satisfy wants rather than needs. (e.g. travel, personal independence).
• Having the opportunity to influence my income by taking on more responsibility.
• Earning a good wage/salary for doing a job (even if I don’t like or enjoy the job).
• Taking an interest in people; e.g. their behaviour, how they differ, their views etc.
• Social contact, friendship and support from other people.
• Giving time to and enjoying my family and/or any persons I am very close to.
• Trying to improve Society/The World for people in general; e.g. politically, economically, socially, environmentally etc.
• Helping individuals with problems with whom I come into contact.
• Having stability and structure in my job; e.g. well ordered, established patterns of work.
• Travel, to experience new places, new landscapes, new cultures etc.
• Engaging in physically challenging activities and risk (e.g. emergency services).
• Feeling in control of my life; being able to act on my own initiative; do things my way.

Below are work related categories; working with People, Data, Things or Ideas, or a combination of each. Using the scale below, indicate in your ‘interest’ level of each statement by writing the appropriate number in the score column. Remember this is about scoring your level of interest in a work related area, and not your skill level in that area.
• Strong Interest • Considerable Interest • Some Interest • No Interest
Your career is a bit like your health, and just as there are things you can do to maintain good health, there are also activities, and tasks that will keep your career healthy.

Task 1 – Work through Tool 1 - Characteristics of a Healthy Career, and consider how healthy your career management is. Use this questionnaire to identify the areas in your career that you consider to be healthy, and which ones you need to develop or work on.
Below are characteristics of a healthy career. Using a 1 to 4 scale (1 being low and 4 high), (identify and press the button) that best represent your position and how healthy your career is.

1. Career Purpose and Goal Research tells us that people who identify goals and have a vision of their future are more successful in achieving what they want, after all. If you aren't sure what you are aiming for, how will you know when you have got there? Think about what you want from your career, and how clear your own career goal is?

2. Marketable Skills As the job market changes so do the skills needed to be successful. It doesn't take long for skills and knowledge to get outdated in a fast changing world, so it’s important to know what your marketable skills are, and what new skills you need to develop for the future.

3. Achievement Focused Your employability will be enhanced by having a reputation of being a high performer. You will be judged by what you deliver and what your key achievements are, and critically the difference you make. Your key achievements need to be quantitate, and measureable such as a monetary value or time saving.

5. Develop a wide network of contacts Your career success will largely depend on the strength of your relationships with others; colleagues, line managers, customers, friends and professional contacts. Networking is something you will do instinctively, to gather information, identify resources, raise your profile, co-ordinate activities and gain support. Consider your own approach to networking.

4. Balance your Life Most people would agree that they are working harder than they used to, and many experience a tension between work and home demands, trying to juggle leisure interests, family commitments, self-development activities and work challenges. It is worth considering what life balance means to you. Balanced career health relies on your physical and mental well being.

6. Promote Yourself Being able to promote yourself to others and being clear about the value of what you do and how you do it will enhance your employability. Maintaining an up to date personal profile or curriculum vitae (internal and external) is part of this process.

7. Manage your Morale Think of a cross section of people you know and split them into two camps; those who are energy drainers, and those who are energy gainers. What distinguishes them? The reality is that invariably we do not respond well to people who are negative and turn everything into a drama. Optimism and positive attitudes are infectious; so be aware of the impression you make to others.

8. Plan for the Future Our needs and wants change. Although the future can be unpredictable you can plan for certain events such as increased family outgoings, change of working pattern and retirement. Financial planning allows you more scope for making the choices you want. Having a clear picture of your financial needs will indicate the type of career you need to maintain.
If you have scored between 0 and 8 your career is very unhealthy and you should complete the full App to kick start your career.

Task; Review your results and consider the questions below:- • Which areas did you score highest in? How are these areas supporting you in your career? • Which areas did you score lowest in? What can you do to improve these scores? If you made these improvements, how would it help you in your career? • What else can you do to improve your overall career health?
If you scored between 8 and 16 your career is unhealthy and you need to develop a number of strategies to help you by completing the full Career Management App.

Task; Review your results and consider the questions below:- • Which areas did you score highest in? How are these areas supporting you in your career? • Which areas did you score lowest in? What can you do to improve these scores? If you made these improvements, how would it help you in your career? • What else can you do to improve your overall career health?
If you have scored between 16 and 24 your career is healthy but there is room for improvement. Dip in and out of the app to help you improve.

Task; Review your results and consider the questions below:- • Which areas did you score highest in? How are these areas supporting you in your career? • Which areas did you score lowest in? What can you do to improve these scores? If you made these improvements, how would it help you in your career? • What else can you do to improve your overall career health?
If you have scored between 24 and 32 your career is very healthy and you may want to get to the next level in your career. Use this App and it will help you get the job you have always wanted.

Task; Review your results and consider the questions below:- • Which areas did you score highest in? How are these areas supporting you in your career? • Which areas did you score lowest in? What can you do to improve these scores? If you made these improvements, how would it help you in your career? • What else can you do to improve your overall career health?

Your key achievements can be anything that is personal, job or role related and shows you’ve made a difference. The more quantifiable you can make your key achievements, the better, and to help you with this it is always worth starting your achievement by using an ‘active verb’ such as reduced, increased, delegated, maintained, improved, designed, launched, managed etc.

Managed the implementation of a major restructuring of personnel policies involving over 500 staff including changes to pay, performance management, working patterns and training programmes for management to support the changes. This was achieved by open communication with union and senior management stakeholders, consulting with staff, and leading a group of project managers and delivering the project within timescales and budget. The changes made resulted in a cost saving of £1.1m in the first year.

The best way to identify your key achievements is to ask yourself a few questions:- • What have I been involved in that’s gone well? • What am I proud about? • What projects or key tasks have I worked on or led?

label.text: Have a look at Tool 6 - Key Achievements to help you create a list of your own key achievements.

label.string: Populate this matrix to help you be specific about your key achievements and the skills used, and difference you made. You will find the information useful in developing your CV.
ACHIEVEMENT Active verbs to describe the achievement.
SKILLS How you achieved it- the skills you used.
OUTCOME The quantifiable or measurable result.
• Changed working patterns for 500 staff.
• Data analysis of existing patterns. • Modelling of different options. • Managed project team and staff. • Communicated regularly with managers and union. • Wrote implementation plan.
• Delivering the project within timescales and budget. • The changes made resulted in a cost saving of £1.1m in the first year.

Many interviewers talk about personal qualities and transferable skills. Your personal qualities are the style or way you do any job (for example being open and friendly), whereas transferable skills are your skills that can be transferred from one occupational environment to another (for example a Teacher can take persuading skills from the classroom into a selling career).
Task; Use Tool 5 – Personal Qualities and Transferable Skills to help you identify your key personal qualities and transferable skills.

Task; Consider these questions
How do your personal qualities match to the job/ career you want? What transferable skills do you have which will match the job/ career you want? What transferable skills do you need to develop to match the job/ career you want?
Use this to help you identify the key skills which you have and use. Go through all the lists and select your KEY personal and transferable skills (max 3 per section).

navigationItem.title: Tool 5 – Personal Qualities and Transferable Skills

state.title: Moving towards the end of your career

navigationItem.title: OPTIONS you can take to get a healthy career.

label.text: Apprenticeships combine practical training in a job with study. An apprentice:

label.string: • works alongside experienced staff • gains job-specific skills • earns a wage • studies towards a related qualification (usually 1 day a week)
Further education (FE) includes any study after secondary education that’s not part of higher education (that is, not taken as part of an undergraduate or graduate degree).

Courses range from basic English and maths to Higher National Diplomas (HNDs). FE also includes technical level qualifications and applied general qualifications, which replace diplomas and vocational qualifications.

Higher education includes an enormous range of courses (degrees, diplomas and master's), with different levels of study, course duration, teaching styles and assessment methods. You can choose from a vast array of courses from Architecture right through to Zoology. Higher education courses are either undergraduate, coming after further education, or postgraduate, coming after you've graduated from an undergraduate degree. You can study high education at universities, colleges and specialist institutes.

label.text: What is an internship/ work experience?

label.string: An internship is a fixed limited period of time spent within industry. With each company it can differ lasting anything from one week to a year and can be part time or full time. As with the length, the payment that is offered depends on the company. You could receive minimum wage, have just your costs covered or in some cases receive nothing at all.

Usually certain jobs are set aside for interns to do, such as helping with a company project. It is a good way to explore an industry and network to build up your contacts for your future career. There are certain industries where an internship, or unpaid work experience, is the only way in for most people.

label.text: Press the Button to display a question.

label.string: After reading through the four different career pathways you may want to think about how you will get to the career you want. Now use the following the virtual career coach to help you plan how you are going to get the career you’ve always wanted.

If you are at a ‘career crossroads’ and thinking about a change, one of the questions you’ll be considering is what are my options? Of course the answer to that question will depend a lot around your personal situation and circumstances, for example the state of your finances, who are your dependants, your age, your knowledge and experience, how mobile you are, the state of your health, and even your approach to risk!

label.text: In this section of the app you will find information around three stages of a career:
3. Moving towards the end of your career

label.string: a. Change of career b. Change of organisation c. Starting your own business

label.text: Typically you spend more time at work than anywhere else and so it’s important to find the right job for you.
Imagine spending 7 hours a day being unhappy in what you do; day in day out, for months and years. What a waste.
People who are happy at work get a sense of achievement from what they do and are more motivated.

label.string: You can either, sit and moan about the job you’re in or fall into ‘just any old job’, or you can take ownership of moving forwards with your career.

• On a scale of 1 -10 how happy are you in your career? • What parts of the job do you enjoy most? • What parts do you enjoy least? • If there was one thing that you would change about your job what would it be? • How up to date is your CV? • When was the last time you spoke to your manager about you and your job? • What do you feel are your strengths? • Why would you say that? What evidence have you got?
Many companies plan for people moving on and ensure that more than one person can cover most tasks at any one time. This helps the transition run more smoothly.

• To what extent does your manager agree that you are ready to look for something more? • What are the additional responsibilities this person has over what you already do? • Where could you begin to assist with some of the tasks this person is doing? • Where/How does this expand your capability? • Besides tasks, what meetings could you start to attend? • What projects could you work on which would raise your profile in show casing your skills and ability?

label.text: You might want to think about whose shoes you’d like to step in to.
“Don’t go to your manager with a problem, go to them with a solution.”
Think bigger than just completing tasks.

label.string:
• Managers look for three main things in a person • Knowledge – Do you know how to do the job? • Skills – Can you apply your knowledge in different situations? How skilled are you? • Attitude – What is your behaviour like? Are you a role model?
What is going to get you noticed at work for all the right reasons?

label.text: The starting point is being able to do your job well.

label.string: • What ideas have you got to improve the way the department operates? • What difference would these improvements make specifically? (time, cost, quality) • What are the steps in making this happen? • Who needs to be involved? • How are you going to present this?

label.text: To become a high performer, a manager is looking for someone who goes above and beyond what is expected.

label.string: You might want to look at ways you think the department could be improved. Are there any processes that could be enhanced? Think it through, don’t go with a statement, go with a fully thought through plan.

navigationItem.title: How to be a high performer

label.string: Many people benefit from having a career coach. Someone who can help them fight through the fog of where they are now through to where they want to be.

label.text: It really helps to be able to talk to someone, who is removed from your day to day role, about your career aspirations.

label.string: Coaching supports you in making informed choices about your way forward. It enables you to be in the driving seat of your career.

• Who is willing to give up some of their time on a regular basis to help you in your career? • Who do you know that can used a guided questioning technique to help you move your career aspirations forward? • Who can you talk to who can give you honest feedback? • Who has the tools and techniques to help you understand what you are good at and which direction might be best for you and your career? • Who will follow up with you and ensure that you carry out your action plans?

Many companies require their staff keep up to date with all the latest information and changes about their role. This ensures that they continue to learn in their job and become even better. It enables staff to reflect on what happened and what they would do differently next time.
Sometimes this requires the colleague to keep a record of what they have done to ensure they are up to date. This is called a Continuous Professional Development log.

• What have you done to ensure that your practices are up to date? • What training or workshops have you attended in the past 12 months? • What did they enable you to do? • Where have you put what you learnt into practice? • What did you learn? • What has changed in the last year? How do you know if you are completing this new task correctly?
It’s never too soon to start planning for your pension. The sooner you start the more time you have to let your investments grow.

• Have you sought advice from a qualified pension provider? • How much are you currently paying into your pension on a monthly basis? • Does your employer contribute towards your pension? • Do you know what it will be worth when you retire? • How much will you need each month to live off?

There are so many companies that are out there now, how do you choose which ones to apply for? Think of yourself as a commodity. What have you got to offer and what do you want in exchange? Try to think ‘outside the box’ here too – e.g. flexible working, evenings and weekends, the culture of the company, travel expectations etc
• What do you want from a company? • What can you offer? • What does xx company offer? • What does xx company want?

label.text: Press the Button to display a question.

label.string: After reading through the four different career pathways you may want to think about how you will get to the career you want. Now use the following the virtual career coach to help you plan how you are going to get the career you’ve always wanted.

state.title: Moving towards the end of your career

label.string: If you choose to be employed, either by your current employer or a new one, it‘s important to consider the benefits and rewards available.

If an organisation is going to be successful, it will need to attract and recruit good workers, and to get workers it needs to be able to offer a good and competitive benefit and reward package to its employees which includes a basic salary, as well as a range of additional incentives and benefits, which is often referred to in job interviews or at the contract of employment stage as the total package.

label.text: Employee Benefits - What do I want?

label.string: So what kind of benefits and rewards are on offer? Tool 8 - Benefits and Rewards outlines the types of incentives that employers may use or include in their ‘total package’. Have a look through, and as part of your decision making process of which jobs are right for you, consider which benefits for you are a ‘Must Have’, which ones are a Nice to Have’ and which ones are ‘Not Needed’ or you can live without? This tool will help you narrow down choice of job, type of employer, and help with negotiating your contract of employment.

label.text: If some of your key motivators are listed below, you may well be suited to running your own business:-

label.string: 1. Being the boss 2. To make money doing something enjoyable 3. Independence 4. Exploring a gap in the market 5. Making more money
Your own business can be a flexible option. Some of the statistics below will help you think through different ways of setting up a business:-

Over the last 10 years, 91% of new firms survived at least six months, with 80% trading for one year and 58% still in existence after 2 years. The riskiest period for the typical firm is between 6 and 24 months, after which the probability of closure declines.

label.text: The motivation for setting up a business

label.string: • 72% of small business start-ups are run by men • 66% of those starting up for the first time are 25 to 44 year olds. • 68% of start-ups are set up by people who have no prior experience of running a business. • 48% of owners start a business in a field where they were previously employed. • 51% of new businesses are set up as sole traders, compared to 31% as limited companies and 18% as partnerships. • 22% of small business owners use their own home as their business base. • The average cost of setting up a business is £18,000, although 29% of businesses cost less than £5000 to start up, and 12% will cost in excess of £50,000 to start up.

Setting up a business takes on average just over 13 weeks – although 22% of owners set up in less than 4 weeks, and 19% takes more than 6 months. Use Tool 9 – Setting up Your Own Business to help you identify the steps you need to take and what you need to do.

label.text: Test out your Idea, product or service.

label.string: If you’re serious about setting up your own business, and you have a business idea, then have a look at Tool 10 – Checklist to Staring a Business, which will help you formulate your idea and start to shape your thinking and planning.

When your idea has been tested, the next step toward launching your business is to scope out and write a business plan. Tool 11 – Developing a Business Plan provides a structure and outline for a robust business plan, which will help to turn your idea or concept into reality!!

• When you reach retirement age you’ll want to continue with a certain standard of living. This is what makes planning for your retirement crucial. • You can usually take a lump sum and/or a monthly income • Collect all your pension information together. This should indicate what to expect as an income from your pension. • Is this enough?

navigationItem.title: Moving towards the end of your career

label.string: Use this Tool, referenced in Carol Pemberton’s book ‘Strike a New Career Deal’ to identify what you offer as an employee to an employer, and what you expect from them in return. Then, consider the questions from the perspective of the employer; what do they want from you as an employee, and what do they offer you as an employer?
This Tool is called the Alignment Model because the more aligned you are with your employer, the stronger the long term employable relationship is.

label.text: What I want from the business
What I offer the business/the job
What the business wants from me
What I offer the business/the job
Most people have three big career options to consider:-

label.string: 1. Stay within your current organisation – either in the same or different job. Advantages are that you know how the organisation works, who the decision makers are, and you may be in a final salary pension scheme. The disadvantages of staying are not developing your wider organisation experience, and may become bored or complacent which can affect your performance.

2. Move to a new organisation - either in a similar type of job or new position. The advantage here is being able to make a new start, embracing all that’s new and different whilst bringing the best from your old organisation to your new one.

3. New lifestyle – making a significant lifestyle change, maybe starting your own business, taking early retirement or going back in to education? The advantages and disadvantages of changing lifestyle will be varied and personal, and will be dependent on your own circumstances and situation.

navigationItem.title: Moving towards the end of your career

label.text: The following matrix will help you assess the risks of change.

label.string: Seeking a job similar to your current one and in the same industry or sector where you can use existing technical and transferable skills and apply sector knowledge is straight forward and considered low risk.

Developing new skills is relatively straight forward; especially if you’re remaining in an industry or sector that you’re familiar with. You’ll be able to use your transferable skills and your knowledge gap will only be around the technical element of your new job. Using your knowledge and skills in a different industry is relatively straight forward. You’ll have good technical and transferable skills, but will have to learn about how the industry or sector works, and get used to new jargon.

Learning and developing new skills in a new industry is clearly a high risk strategy. For most people it becomes impractical and unrealistic. Changing complete career direction isn’t impossible, and a wide transferable skills base will be very helpful.

label.text: Use Tool 7 – Career Options to identify the pro’s and con’s for each.

label.string: It’s important for CV’s to be visually attractive and easy to read. Too much information will detract from the message you want to get across, ideally your CV should be no more than two pages of A4, well laid out, with sufficient white space that doesn’t make it look too busy, and professional by using margins, bold type and bullets, as well as clear fonts such as Arial or Tahoma in size 11 or 12.

label.text: As a minimum, your CV should include the following information

label.string: • Contact Details – Name, home/contact address, email address and telephone number.

• Personal Profile – Headline paragraph, describing who you are, your main attributes, and what you offer the employer. This is the first thing the reader will look at, so if it is not attention grabbing, or doesn’t describe the type of person who the reader is looking for, then it’s unlikely that they’ll read on!

• Skills and Achievements – Details of your transferable skills, activities and the achievements that best represent your suitability for the job in question. And remember that your achievements must be quantifiable and results orientated.
• Career History - A reverse chronological record of your job experience, including job title, the organisation, and what your main responsibilities and achievements were.

• Education and Training – Include your highest qualifications first, and any relevant training or continuous professional development (CPD) achievements. Employers are less likely to be interested in your GCSE’s if you have higher education qualifications, such as a Degree or professional qualification.

• Personal Information – The point of including some personal information is to tell the reader a little more about who you are and some of your interests, especially if they are relevant to the skills of the job. For example, if driving or travel is a key part of the job, you may want to mention that you have a clean driving licence or you enjoy travelling and finding new places. You are best advised to avoid things like physical appearance, religious/political affiliations that could be prejudicial, or reasons for leaving your company.

label.text: What does a Good CV look like?

label.string: There are two styles of CV’s; Chronological and Functional CV.
In this type of CV you start with your last job and work backwards. This enables your most recent job to be given prominence, making an immediate impact on the recruiter.
This type of CV emphasises key areas of achievements, skills and strengths and directs the CV towards a targeted, career area.

• Your CV is easy to read, concise (less is more). • Your CV is factual, informative and succinct, presenting a professional and business-like image. • Every word used is relevant. • It is attention grabbing and memorable, letting your personality show through. • It is full of action words concentrating on more recent experience, rather than earlier life and career. • It sells you in the first paragraph (this has the most impact).

• It provides a mental picture of who you are, what you are about and what you can offer. • It does justice to your achievements, skills and qualities and is not just your life history or an inventory of the tasks you have performed and responsibilities and job functions you have had. • It highlights your positive, relevant and interesting achievements, successes, benefits and personal attributes. • It identifies your unique selling points. • It is relevant to any application you are making or likely to make i.e. clearly illustrates how you match the selection criteria.

• Your achievements begin with an action verb ‘developed, created, sold, saved, reduced, increased etc). • You’ve specified and quantified the result or impact you had on the organisation, including numerical measurement. A well informed achievement is composed of five parts:- 1. Firstly, the problem or major undertaking you were faced with. 2. How you solved/handled it. 3. Difficulties or hurdles you overcame. 4. What you actually accomplished. 5. The measurement of benefit to the organisation e.g. reduced absenteeism from 8% to 3%, resulting in a saving £100,000 in labour costs.
What are my ‘Unique Selling Points’, or USP’s in my CV? These are the additional capabilities which you have but your competitors don’t have. They emphasise where you stand out from your peer group.

For example:- • Languages - spoken and written to commercial standard. • A willingness to travel extensively in your work, or relocate. • Evidence that you can effectively manage a large team - state size of team you have managed. • How you solved a particular problem in a previous job which may be applicable to a new position. • Business awareness.

What does the job involve? • Range of things that I will be asked to do? • Personal qualities I will need to do the job well? • Skills I will need to do the job well? • Do you know the selection criteria, how can I find out what people are looking for? • What relevant experience do I have? • Can I remember when and how I developed these skills and when I demonstrated using them?

Preparation is a key part of any interview process - you only have one chance to make a good first impression. So, as soon as you’ve been invited to attend an interview it is probably worth finding out a little more about the interview itself. Some useful questions may be:-

• What is the format of the interview? • How long will the interview last? • Are there any exercises? • Do I need to prepare anything? • Are there any other tests or selection methods being used? • Who will be interviewing you and their position within the company? You may want to find out a bit about them before you meet.

label.text: Also it is worth checking that you know where the interview is being held, and to make sure that you:

label.string: • know how to get to the venue and how long the journey takes. • have maps, train times, etc, in advance. • check for any planned disruptions to road or rail services. • leave plenty of time so you are not rushing. • find out if travel and overnight accommodation are paid for. • check the physical access to the premises and indicate any additional support that you might require in the interview. • dress appropriately for the position for which you are being interviewed. Some companies have a much more relaxed approach to dress than others. If in doubt, wear a suit.

It is important to think about how you might answer certain types of question. How will you provide evidence of certain qualities? If you are asked about being a team player, what evidence will you use to show this? Make sure you cover the three main areas below in your mental preparation:-

It is important to remind yourself of the messages you have conveyed through your CV/application form and be prepared to discuss anything you have included. Read through your application and imagine you are the interviewer. What questions would you ask in their position? Make sure you can give at least one positive example (preferably more) for each of the skills and attributes the employer is seeking.

It is important that you know as much as possible about the job you are applying for. If possible, speak to people already doing the type of work you are interested in. Increasingly, employers are adding case studies of employees to their websites, which can provide an interesting insight into the day-to-day activities of certain roles.

This will demonstrate your interest and enthusiasm for working for this particular organisation and will help you to prepare some questions to ask the interviewer. All employers will expect you to display some understanding of their business, its size and the sector in which it operates. Memorising the year’s financial performance is not necessary but it is important to read recent information about the organisation and to be aware of the market that it operates in.

Many employer websites have press archives of articles that have been issued by them or that have appeared in the local/national press. Make sure that you are up to date with developments in the sector to which you are applying.

You do not need to know exactly what you would be doing but an understanding of the types of activities you would be involved in will help. Refer to the job advertisement, job description or person specification which you should have obtained from the employer.

You may feel that there are certain questions that have the potential to flummox you. These may include questions that appear to be an invitation to shoot yourself in the foot and those that ask you to think about yourself in a different way.

label.text: There are typically three types of interview question:

label.string: 1) Situational questions – the interviewer asks you to describe how you would handle a situation. To respond to this type of question, give a high level overview of what you would do, and follow this up with an example of how you have done this in your experience.

2) Performance based questions – the interviewer asks you to describe what you did in a situation. To respond to this type of question, use an example you are comfortable with and proud of. To answer fully, tell the story clearly – the situation was….I did….and the outcome was…. Be prepared for follow up questions that probe your achievements, such as “What was the impact on the business? What did you learn? What went wrong?”

3) General/Personal questions – the interviewer asks direct questions about your: • Skills – What are your strengths? What are your weaknesses? • Experience – Tell me about your current job. What is your proudest achievement? • Motivation – Why do you want this job? • Education and Training – Tell me about your college course. • Interests – What do you like about fly fishing?

label.text: Press the Button to display a random question.

textView.string: Most people feel nervous about interviews. Above all, try and stay positive and remember that it’s a learning experience and there is no right or wrong. Try positive affirmations to eliminate any negative feelings. Identify your main concern about the interview (e.g. ‘everyone else will be better than me’) and write yourself a positive statement, in the first person and in the present tense, to address it. You might try ‘I am a strong candidate for the job’. Relax and say your positive affirmation to yourself - out loud if you can - at the start of the day and repeat it whenever you are feeling nervous. For more information on how to prepare for an interview contact Aspire Development on 01422 241946 or office@aspiredevelopment.co.uk

label.string: With thorough preparation, you are in a good position to sell yourself and your skills at the interview, by responding effectively to questions and displaying knowledge of yourself, the job and the organisation to which you are applying.

• Be prepared to talk - avoid yes/no answers and expand as often as possible. Don’t, however, over-communicate; it can be tempting to talk too much. Don’t talk yourself out of a job trying to fill silences left by the interviewer! Take your cue from the interviewer and, if you are not sure that they have heard enough, ask if they would like you to continue.
• If you need a moment’s thinking time, take a sip of water, if available - this will provide you with an opportunity to think about your answer.
• Ask for clarification if you need it - this not only helps you to answer the question asked but also demonstrates confidence and control.
• Use examples from several different experiences, rather than concentrating on just one aspect of your life.

• Be positive – avoid the word ‘but’. Many people play down good experiences, saying things like: ‘yes, I have worked as part of a team but that was only in a bar at weekends’. A more positive summary would be: ‘I worked in a busy bar at weekends with three other staff and we needed to work well as a team in order to keep the queues down and keep our motivation up’.

• Be yourself - if you adopt a new persona for the interview, the result is likely to be insincere and transparent. Even if you are offered the job, you may find later that it’s not right for the ‘real’ you.

• Remember that honesty is the best policy. If it is discovered at a later stage that you have been dishonest, you could be dismissed. Admitting to a period of poor motivation during your A-levels shows more integrity than blaming someone else for your grades. Don’t feel that you should cover up incidents like this; rather present them as positive learning experiences.
There is a technique called STAR which is useful to help you structure interview responses. The STAR technique is a pneumonic that stands for:-
Situation - What was the situation? What was the background and context?

label.text: Task- What specific task did you need to accomplish?

label.string: Action- What specifically did you say and do? What were the actions you took?
Result- What were the results of your actions? What was the impact? What did you learn?

Prepare two or three questions to ask the interviewer or panel. For example you could ask them to tell you about the company culture. This can also be a good opportunity to reveal positive aspects about yourself that the interviewer’s questions may not have elicited. Good questions to ask are those that demonstrate your eagerness to develop within the organisation and take on responsibility. Questions about training or what the process is for progression in the company are also a good idea but make sure these are relevant to the organisation. This is also a good opportunity for you to demonstrate your research into the organisation by asking questions about relevant articles you may have read, for example: “I read in the newspaper last week that you are expanding into Europe. Is the company thinking of expanding into any other markets?”
• Show an interest - ask about the job, organisation, employees, products and processes;
• Ask the interviewer when you can expect to hear from them
• Don’t ask about pay, pensions or other perks - it is not appropriate at this stage;
• Don’t ask questions that have been answered in the brochure or other literature sent out with the invitation to interview.

First impressions are crucial. An interview may last for 45 minutes or more but studies have shown that someone forms judgements about you within four minutes of meeting you and these judgments affect their subsequent impressions. Research shows that first impressions are made up of the following:
• 55% visual impact; i.e. dress, facial expressions, smiling, open body language etc.
• 38% tone of voice; i.e. speaking quietly, softly, loudly, with emotion, expression and using intonation.
• 7% the words you use.

navigationItem.title: Questions you could ask the interviewer.

label.string: • How you look - sit reasonably upright - slouching or leaning too far back in your chair can give the impression that you are too casual about the whole thing. Don’t cross your arms as it can make you appear defensive. Moderate hand movements are perfectly acceptable and can enliven the conversation.

• Eye contact - good eye contact is essential and is an excellent way of conveying your interest in the job. Looking downwards or at anything other than the interviewer can make you appear disinterested and insincere. Maintaining good eye contact can also help you gauge the interviewer’s reaction to what you are saying (to see whether you should be expanding on your answers). With panel interviews, the best advice is to look at and answer the person asking the questions, with a glance from time to time at the other interviewers.

• The style, tone and delivery of your voice - try not to talk too fast and keep your tone moderate. This can be difficult when you are nervous but take a deep breath before you start to answer a question and work on keeping your answers concise. Rehearse your answers beforehand, and ask a friend or colleague to give you feedback on how you speak.

• Pick out any key words or phrases – use the job description or company website to get a feel for the type of language the business uses. If the interviewer specifically talks about ‘customer service’ then match their language, rather than talking about ‘servicing clients’.
• Don’t use slang - watch out for too many ‘ers’ and ‘ums’. Practising beforehand, especially in front of someone else, can help you identify any bad habits.

navigationItem.title: Questions you could ask the interviewer.
STRATEGIES to getting a healthy career.
